render.tex: \title{Equation of Plane} \\ %text Cartesian and Vector forms of equation a plane in three dimensional space %

reason.tex: %text A plane in 3d space is given by, % \begin{align} ax+by+cz=d \end{align} \\ %text The same equation in vector form is expressed as, % \begin{align} \ora{r}\cdot(\vector{a}{b}{c})=d \end{align} \\ %text The constants $a$, $b$ and $c$ represent the direction ratios of the normal to the plane. If $l$, $m$ and $n$ represent the direction cosines of the normal to the plane then to evaluate these we would do the following, % \begin{align} l&=\dfrac{a}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}}, \\ m&=\dfrac{b}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}}, \\ n&=\dfrac{c}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}} \end{align} \\ %text Dividing both sides of the cartesian equation by $\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}$, the equation of the plane becomes, % \begin{align} lx+my+nz&=\dfrac{d}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}} \\ lx+my+nz&=d_\perp \end{align} \\ %text The right hand side of the above equation represents the $\perp$ distance from origin to the plane. %
